"sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/tory-candidate-cooperating-betting-watchdog-171004772.html", "title": "Tory candidate cooperating with betting watchdog", "body": "A Conservative candidate alleged to have bet on the timing of the general election has confirmed she is cooperating with the Gambling Commission.\n\nLaura Saunders, the party's candidate in Bristol North West, says she is also considering legal action against the BBC, which first revealed the betting regulator was looking into her.\n\nThe BBC said in a statement that it was confident in its journalism.\n\nIt is not known when the bet was placed or for how much money.\n\nMs Saunders' husband, the Conservative Party's director of campaigning Tony Lee is also being looked into by the betting watchdog over an alleged bet relating to the timing of the 4 July election.\n\nA statement released via solicitors said: \"Ms Saunders will be co-operating with the Gambling Commission and has nothing further to add.\n\n\"It is inappropriate to conduct any investigation of this kind via the media, and doing so risks jeopardising the work of the Gambling Commission and the integrity of its investigation.\n\n\"The publication of the BBC's story is premature and is a clear infringement of Ms Saunders' privacy rights.\n\n\"She is considering legal action against the BBC and any other publishers who infringe her privacy rights.\"\n\nA BBC spokesperson said: \"We are confident in our journalism.\n\n\"As Laura Saunders is a candidate standing for election, it is clearly in the public interest to report allegations made against her.\"\n\nLabour and the Liberal Democrats have both called on the Conservatives to suspend Ms Saunders and Craig Williams as Conservative candidates over political bets.\n\nLast week Mr Williams, who had been a parliamentary aide to Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, apologised and said he had made a \"huge error of judgement\" over betting on the date of the general election.\n\nMr Williams, the Conservative candidate for Montgomeryshire and Glyndwr, allegedly placed a \u00a3100 bet on a July election three days before Mr Sunak announced the date.\n\nMr Sunak's announced 4 July as the date of the general election on 22 May, taking much of Westminster by surprise.\n\nA Conservative Party spokesman told the BBC: \"We have been contacted by the Gambling Commission about a small number of individuals.\"\n\nThe party said it would not be proper to comment further until any process was finished.\n\nIf someone uses confidential information to gain an unfair advantage when betting, this could be a criminal offence under section 42 of the Gambling Act.\n\nOn Wednesday, it emerged that a police officer working as part of the prime minister's close protection team had been arrested following an allegation of bets on the timing of the election.\n\nThe officer was initially suspended by the Metropolitan Police and then arrested on suspicion of misconduct in public office.\n\nThe individual has been bailed pending further inquiries.\n\nThe Met was contacted by the Gambling Commission last Friday. It informed the force that it was investigating alleged bets made by a police constable from the Met's Royalty and Specialist Protection Command.\n\nA spokesperson for the Gambling Commission said: \"The Gambling Commission regulates gambling in the interests of consumers and the wider public.\n\n\"Currently the Commission is investigating the possibility of offences concerning the date of the election. This is an ongoing investigation, and the Commission cannot provide any further details at this time.\n\n\"We are not confirming or denying the identity of any individuals involved in this election", "body": "One of Rishi Sunak's close protection officers has been arrested over alleged bets about the timing of the election.\n\nThe officer was arrested on Monday on suspicion of misconduct in public office, the Metropolitan police said in a statement\n\nThe news comes a week on from the Guardian's revelation that Rishi Sunak's closest parliamentary aide, Craig Williams, placed a \u00a3100 bet on a July election just three days before the prime minister named the date.\n\nAs a result of that incident, the Gambling Commission did a wider investigation and found information that led to the decision to investigate the officer.\n\nThe Metropolitan police said it was contacted last Friday by the Gambling Commission, which informed the force that it was investigating alleged bets related to the timing of an election by a constable from the Met's Royalty and Specialist Protection Command.\n\n\"The matter was immediately referred to officers in the Met's Directorate of Professional Standards, who opened an investigation, and the officer was also removed from operational duties,\" the force said.\n\nThe matter has also been referred to the Independent Office for Police Conduct, which is responsible for overseeing the system for handling complaints made against police forces in England and Wales\n\nThe Met added: \"The Gambling Commission continues to lead the investigation into the alleged betting offences, and our investigation is running in parallel to that.\"\n\nThe Guardian reported last week that the gambling Commission launched an inquiry after Williams, the prime minister's parliamentary private secretary placed a bet with the bookmaker Ladbrokes on Sunday 19 May in his local constituency of Montgomeryshire and Glynd\u0175r.\n\nWilliams said in a statement last week: \"I put a flutter on the general election some weeks ago. This has resulted in some routine inquiries and I confirm I will fully cooperate with these.\"\n\n\"I don't want it to be a distraction from the campaign, I should have thought how it looks.\"\n\nThe Gambling Commission has asked bookmakers to trawl through all substantial bets placed on a July election after it was flagged that Williams had put the wager on the poll date just days before it was announced.\n\nMembers of the Met's Royalty and Specialist Protection Command operate in close proximity to the prime minister and his team, often sharing the same vehicle.\n\nAsked about the police officer, a spokesperson for the Gambling Commission said: \"Currently the Commission is investigating the possibility of offences concerning the date of the election. "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/pms-police-officer-arrested-over-165424505.html", "title": "PM's protection officer arrested over alleged bets", "body": "A police officer working as part of the prime minister's close protection team has been arrested over alleged bets about the timing of the general election, the BBC has learned.\n\nThe officer was initially suspended by the Metropolitan Police and then arrested on suspicion of misconduct in public office.\n\nMr Sunak announced 4 July as the date of the general election on 22 May, taking much of Westminster by surprise.\n\nThe Gambling Commission is looking into alleged betting offences connected to the date of the election.\n\nThe Met was contacted by the watchdog last Friday, which informed the force that it was investigating alleged bets made by a police constable from the Met's Royalty and Specialist Protection Command.\n\nThe Met told the BBC: \"The matter was immediately referred to officers in the Met's Directorate of Professional Standards, who opened an investigation, and the officer was also removed from operational duties.\"\n\nThe officer was arrested on Monday, then taken into custody and bailed pending further enquiries.\n\nThe matter has also been referred to the Independent Office for Police Conduct.\n\nThe Met Police said the Gambling Commission continues to lead the investigation into the alleged betting offences, and \"our investigation is running in parallel to that\".\n\nA spokesperson for the Gambling Commission said it \"regulates gambling in the interests of consumers and the wider public.\"\n\n\"Currently the commission is investigating the possibility of offences concerning the date of the election,\" the statement said.\n\nResponding to the arrest, Liberal Democrat deputy leader Daisy Cooper said: \"Rishi Sunak must call a Cabinet Office inquiry into what is shaping up to be yet another scandal at the heart of government.\n\n\"This stinks of yet more sleaze and answers are needed.\n\n\"An inquiry is needed to understand who knew what and when.\"\n\nSeparately, one of Rishi Sunak's closest aides, Craig Williams, was alleged to have placed a You can check out at any time. More info\n\nA police constable working as part of Rishi Sunak's protection team has been arrested over alleged bets made related to the timing of the General Election. The officer was taken into custody on Monday on suspicion of misconduct in a public office and has since been bailed pending further inquiries, says the Metropolitan Police.\n\nIn a statement, the force said it was informed by the Gambling Commission a police constable from the Met's Royalty and Specialist Protection Command was being investigated over the alleged bets. Police said the matter was immediately referred to the Met's Directorate of Professional Standards and the officer was also removed from operational duties\n\n.The matter has been referred to the Independent Office for Police Conduct (IOPC), the force added. The Gambling Commission is leading the investigation into the alleged betting offences, which is running parallel to the Met's probe.\n\nIn a statement, the Gambling Commission said: \"Currently the commission is investigating the possibility of offences concerning the date of the election. This is an ongoing investigation, and the commission cannot provide any further details at this time.\"\n\nRishi Sunak previously said it was \"very disappointing\" one of his closest aides and the He was taken into custody and bailed pending further enquiries. The matter has also been referred to the Independent Office for Police Conduct.\n\n\"The Gambling Commission continues to lead the investigation into the alleged betting offences, and our investigation is running in parallel to that.\"\n\nThe Gambling Commission in the UK has said it is investigating \"the possibility of offences concerning the date of the election\".\n\nA spokesperson said: \"The Gambling Commission regulates gambling in the interests of consumers and the wider public.\n\n\"Currently the commission is investigating the possibility of offences concerning the date of "title": "Tory candidate 'to cooperate' with watchdog over election date bet", "body": "By Greg Heffer, Political Correspondent and David Wilcock, Deputy Political Editor For Mailonline\n\nA Tory candidate facing a probe over allegedly betting on the date of the general election has said she will 'be cooperating with the Gambling Commission'.\n\nLaura Saunders, who is standing in Bristol North West, is the subject of an inquiry over an alleged wager on Rishi Sunak going to the polls on 4 July.\n\nShe is the second Tory candidate to be investigated by the Commission, which is also looking into a bet placed by Craig Wiliiams, a close aide of the Prime Minister.\n\nIn a statement released through her solicitor, Ms Saunders said she would be 'co-operating with the Gambling Commission and has nothing further to add'.\n\nThe statement also warned she is considering legal action against the BBC, who first reported the alleged bet, and 'any other publishers who infringe her privacy rights'.\n\nIt emerged earlier that Ms Saunders is married to the Conservatives' director of campaigning Tony Lee, who is also being investigated according to the BBC.\n\nThe Tories confirmed Mr Lee has taken a 'leave of absence' from his party role.\n\nCommunities Secretary Michael Gove admitted this morning that it would be 'reprehensible' to use inside information to bet on the general election date, adding: 'It doesn't look great.'\n\nLabour leader Keir Starmer said: 'This candidate should be suspended and it's very telling that Rishi Sunak has not already done that.\n\n'If it was one of my candidates, they'd be gone and their feet would not have touched the floor.'\n\nLaura Saunders, who is standing in Bristol North West, is the subject of an inquiry by the Gambling Commission over an alleged wager on Rishi Sunak going to the polls in July.\n\nIt emerged earlier that Ms Saunders is married to the Conservatives ' director of campaigning Tony Lee, who is also being investigated according to the BBC\n\nCommunities Secretary Michael Gove admitted this morning that it would be 'reprehensible' to use inside information to bet on the general election date, adding: 'It doesn't look great.'\n\nLabour leader Keir Starmer said: 'This candidate should be suspended and it's very telling that Rishi Sunak has not already done that.'\n\nIn a statement released on Ms Saunders' behalf, Nama Zarroug, a solicitor at Astraea Linskills, said: 'As the Conservative Party has already stated, investigations are ongoing.\n\n'Ms Saunders will be co-operating with the Gambling Commission and has nothing further to add.\n\n'It is inappropriate to conduct any investigation of this kind via the media, and doing so risks jeopardising the work of the Gambling Commission and the integrity of its investigation.\n\n'The publication of the BBC's story is premature and is a clear infringement of Ms Saunders' privacy rights.\n\n'She is considering legal action against the BBC and any other publishers who infringe her privacy rights.'\n\nOn the Tory campaign battle bus in London, Mr Gove told broadcasters: 'Obviously, it doesn't look great. And, obviously, the conclusions lots of people are drawing are not at all great.\n\n'But I don't know all the facts at the moment. I'd be loath to condemn without there being an investigation that's been concluded.'\n\nA Conservative spokesman said: 'We have been contacted by the Gambling Commission about a small number of individuals.\n\n'As the Gambling Commission is an independent body, it wouldn't be proper to comment further, until any process is concluded.'\n\nMr Williams is also being investigated after putting a \u00a3100 bet on the election being held in July, just days before the PM announced the July 4 vote. The 5-1 flutter would have netted him \u00a3500.\n\nThe issue with those with close connections to the PM placing a bet on the election date comes with the individual having possible inside information that could give them an advantage.\n\nIt has not been confirmed whether Ms Saunders had any inside information when allegedly placing the bet.\n\nThe use of confidential information to gain unfair advantage when betting may constitute a criminal offence of cheating under section 42 of the Gambling Act.\n\nThose convicted face and unlimited fine or up to two years in jail.\n\nRead More Sunak aide investigated for placing \u00a3100 bet on July election days before PM set July 4 date\n\nThe investigation regarding Ms Saunders also comes as a police officer in Mr Sunak's close protection team has been suspended and arrested over alleged bets about the timing of the election, it was revealed on Wednesday.\n\nThe Metropolitan Police was contacted by the Gambling Commission last Friday and told the commission was investigating the activities of a member of Scotland Yard's Royalty and Specialist Protection (RaSP) command.\n\nThe police constable was removed from operational duties with immediate effect.\n\nA Met Police spokesperson said: 'We can confirm that on Friday, 14 June, the Met were contacted by the Gambling Commission who informed us that they were investigating alleged bets made by a Police Constable from the Met's Royalty and Specialist Protection Command, which were related to the timing of the General Election.\n\n'The matter was immediately referred to officers in the Met's Directorate of Professional Standards, who opened an investigation, and the officer was also removed from operational duties.\n\n'The officer was subsequently arrested on Monday 17 June on suspicion of misconduct in public office. He was taken into custody and bailed pending further enquiries. The matter has also been referred to the Independent Office for Police Conduct.\n\n'The Gambling Commission continues to lead the investigation into the alleged betting offences, and our investigation is running in parallel to that.'\n\nThe issue with those with close connections to Rishi Sunak (pictured) placing a bet on the election date comes with the individual having possible inside information\n\nCraig Williams (pictured), Mr Sunak's parliamentary private secretary, is also being investigated after putting a \u00a3100 bet on the election being held in July\n\nMr Williams, who is standing for re-election as MP in Montgomeryshire, bet on the election being held in July just three days before the announcement was made, The Guardian first reported.\n\nMeanwhile, the nation was surprised the election was going to be held in summer rather than autumn. Mr Williams has since apologised for a 'huge error of judgement'.\n\nThe date and value of Ms Saunder's alleged bet have not been revealed.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", in Sunak's protection team arrested over UK election date betting scandal", "body": "LONDON, June 20 -- A police constable working as part of British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's protection team has been arrested over alleged bets made related to the timing of the UK's general election, reported German news agency (dpa).\n\nThe Metropolitan Police said the officer was taken into custody on Monday on suspicion of misconduct in a public office and has since been bailed pending further inquiries.\n\nIn a statement, the force said it was informed by the Gambling Commission that a police constable from the Met's Royalty and Specialist Protection Command was being investigated over the alleged bets.\n\nPolice said the matter was immediately referred to the Met's Directorate of Professional Standards and the officer was also removed from operational duties.\n\nThe matter has been referred to the Independent Office for Police Conduct (IOPC), which said they will \"make a decision on the level of IOPC involvement in due course\".\n\nThe Gambling Commission is leading the investigation into the alleged betting offences, which is running parallel to the Met's probe.\n\nIn a statement, the Gambling Commission said: \"Currently the commission is investigating the possibility of offences concerning the date of the election.\"\n\n\"This is an ongoing investigation, and the commission cannot provide any further details at this time.\"\n\nAccording to the Crown Prosecution Service's website, misconduct in a public office \"concerns serious wilful abuse or neglect of the power or responsibilities\".\n\nSunak previously said it was \"very disappointing\" that one of his closest aides and the current Conservative candidate for Montgomeryshire and Glyndwr in Wales, Craig Williams, had allegedly placed a bet on the date of the general election.\n\nWilliams, who was the Tory Member of Parliament for Montgomery until the election was called, is alleged to have placed a \u00a3100 (RM599) bet on a July polling day some three days before Sunak named the date as July 4, at a Ladbrokes betting shop in his constituency.\n\nHe previously said he had clearly made a \"huge The officer was subsequently arrested on Monday 17 June on suspicion of misconduct in public office.\"\n\nThe Met said the arrested officer had been taken into custody and bailed \"pending further inquiries\". The matter had also been referred to the force watchdog, the Independent Office for Police Conduct, it added.\n\nThe Met did not name the officer, in line with normal practice before anyone is charged.\n\nWilliams insisted when admitting making the bet that the Gambling Commission's investigation of the matter amounted to \"some routine inquiries\" with which he would \"fully co-operate\". He remains the Conservative general election candidate for Montgomeryshire and Glyndwr in Wales.\n\nThe Guardian reported he had bet \u00a3100 on May 19 at odds of 5-1 that the election would be in July, at a time when it was not expected before the autumn. Sunak made his surprise announcement of a July 4 election on May 22.\n\nThe police officer is the only person known to have been arrested.\n\nThe Gambling Commission said it was investigating the \"possibility\" of offences concerning the date of the election.\n\n\"This is an ongoing investigation, and the Commission cannot provide any further details at this time,\" it said.", "source": The BBC reported earlier that Mr Lee - who took a leave of absence from his job on Wednesday afternoon - is married to a Conservative candidate who is being looked into by the betting industry regulator.Laura Saunders, the party's candidate in Bristol North West, has worked for the Tories since 2015 and is married to Mr Lee. It is not known when either individual placed a bet or for how much money. Laura Saunders and Tony Lee have been approached for comment by the BBC and have not responded. A Conservative Party spokesman told the BBC: \"We have been contacted by the Gambling Commission about a small number of individuals. \"As the Gambling Commission is an independent body, it wouldn't be proper to comment further, until any process is concluded.\"A spokesperson for the Gambling Commission said: \"The Gambling Commission regulates gambling in the interests of consumers and the wider public. \"Currently the Commission is investigating the possibility of offences concerning the date of the election. This is an ongoing investigation, and the Commission cannot provide any further details at this time.\"We are not confirming or denying the identity of any individuals involved in this investigation.\"If someone uses confidential information to gain an unfair advantage when betting, this could be a criminal offence under section 42 of the Gambling Act. Mr Sunak announced 4 July as the date of the general election on 22 May, taking much of Westminster by surprise.Last week it was alleged that one of Rishi Sunak's closest aides, Craig Williams, placed a \u00a3100 bet on a July polling day three days before the PM named the date .Mr Williams, who was the Tory MP for Montgomery until the election was called and is standing again in the new constituency of Montgomeryshire and Glyndwr, previously apologised and said he made a \"huge error of judgement\". When asked by the BBC, he refused to say whether he placed a bet on the basis of inside information.Labour and the Liberal Democrats have both called for Ms Saunders and Mr Williams to be suspended as Conservative candidates.Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer said: \"It's very telling that Rishi Sunak has not already done that.\"If it was one of my candidates, they'd be gone and their feet would not have touched the floor.\"Lib Dem deputy leader Daisy Cooper said: \"It would be an utter disgrace if Conservative politicians were shown to be more focussed on turning a quick buck rather than the needs of the country.\"Housing Secretary Michael Gove said it would be \"deeply wrong\" if anyone had used \"inside information\" to place bets.\"What I can't do is sort of get too much into the detail of the case while an investigation is going on,\" he told the BBC\"But I can talk about the broad principle and you're absolutely right, it's reprehensible.\"On Wednesday, it emerged that a police officer working as part of the prime minister's close protection team had been arrested following an allegation of bets on the timing of the election.The officer was initially suspended by the Metropolitan Police and then arrested on suspicion of misconduct in public office.The individual has been bailed pending further inquiries.The Met was contacted by the Gambling Commission last Friday. It informed the force that it was investigating alleged bets made by a police constable from the Met's Royalty and Specialist Protection Command.Labour's campaign coordinator Pat McFadden ...", {"uri": "8187247784", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "14:54:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T14:54:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T14:53:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.covers.com/industry/arrest-made-in-connection-to-uk-election-betting-scandal-june-20-2024", "title": "Arrest Made in Connection to UK Election Betting Scandal", "body": "Police constable from the Met's Royalty and Specialist Protection Command arrested, under investigation over alleged bets.\n\nA police officer has been arrested in connection to the UK's emerging election betting scandal. The officer, who worked as part of the prime minister's close protection team, was suspended by the Metropolitan Police prior to his arrest.\n\nLast Friday, the Met was informed by the regulator that a police constable from the Met's Royalty and Specialist Protection Command was under investigation over alleged bets. The officer was arrested on suspicion of misconduct in a public office on Monday, and has now been bailed pending further enquiries.\n\nClose protection officers are specialist bodyguards responsible for the protection of high-profile individuals such as government ministers.\n\n\"We can confirm that on Friday, 14 June, the Met were contacted by the Gambling Commission who informed us that they were investigating alleged bets made by a Police Constable from the Met's Royalty and Specialist Protection Command, which were related to the timing of the general election,\" a spokesperson for Scotland Yard said, speaking to The Independent.\n\n\"The matter was immediately referred to officers in the Met's Directorate of Professional Standards, who opened an investigation, and the officer was also removed from operational duties.\"\n\nThe Gambling Commission is currently investigating all significant bets placed on the July election, in the three weeks preceding Sunak's announcement.\n\nConcerns were raised initially when senior aide and Conservative candidate Craig Williams was found to have placed a bet on the date of the election three days prior to it being announced.\n\nJust days ago, the regulator wrote to all licensed bookmakers to request data on any bets where customers stood to win more than \u00a3199 by betting on the election date. The three-page letter asked for the bookmakers' cooperation with the ongoing investigation, and confirmed the regulator's concerns about betting integrity around the election date.\n\nOn Wednesday evening, it was revealed that another Conservative candidate is now being looked into by the Gambling Commission. The candidate in question, Laura Saunders, is married to Tony Lee, the party's Director of Campaigns.\n\nSaunders is currently standing as the Conservative candidate in Bristol North West.\n\n\"We have been contacted by the Gambling Commission about a small number of individuals. As the Gambling Commission is an independent body, it wouldn't be proper to comment further, until any process is concluded,\" a Conservative Party spokesperson said to BBC News.\n\nCalls for an inquiry into the emerging scandal are now growing, particularly amongst opposition parties.\n\n\"Rishi Sunak must call a Cabinet Office inquiry into what is shaping up to be yet another scandal at the heart of Government,\" said Daisy Cooper, deputy leader of the Liberal Democrats.\n\n\"This stinks of yet more sleaze and answers are needed. An inquiry is needed to understand who knew what and when.\"\n\nThe Gambling Commission regulates gambling in the interests of consumers and the public.\n\n\"Currently the commission is investigating the possibility of offences concerning the date of the election,\" a spokesperson said. \"This is an ongoing investigation, and the commission cannot provide any further details at this time.\"", The Conservatives confirmed Mr Lee has taken a 'leave of absence' from his party role.\n\nCommunities Secretary Michael Gove admitted this morning that it would be 'reprehensible' to use inside information to bet on the General Election date, adding: 'It doesn't look great.'\n\nLabour leader Keir Starmer said: 'This candidate should be suspended and it's very telling that Rishi Sunak has not already done that.\n\n'If it was one of my candidates, they'd be gone and their feet would not have touched the floor.'\n\nLaura Saunders, who is standing in Bristol North West, is the subject of an inquiry by the Gambling Commission over an alleged wager on Rishi Sunak going to the polls in July.\n\nToday it emerged that Ms Saunders is marred to Tony Lee, who is also being investigated, according to the BBC . Sources confirmed Mr Lee has taken a 'leave of absence' from his party role.\n\nCommunities Secretary Michael Gove admitted this morning that it would be 'reprehensible' to use inside information to bet on the General Election date, adding: 'It doesn't look great.'\n\nLabour leader Keir Starmer said: 'This candidate should be suspended and it's very telling that Rishi Sunak has not already done that.'\n\nOn the Tory campaign battle bus in London, Mr Gove told broadcasters: 'Obviously, it doesn't look great. And, obviously, the conclusions lots of people are drawing are not at all great.\n\n'But I don't know all the facts at the moment. I'd be loath to condemn without there being an investigation that's been concluded.'\n\nA Conservative spokesman said: 'We have been contacted by the Gambling Commission about a small number of individuals.\n\n'As the Gambling Commission is an independent body, it wouldn't be proper to comment further, until any process is concluded.'\n\nMr Williams is also being investigated after putting a \u00a3100 bet on the election being held in July, just days before the Prime Minister announced the July 4 vote. The 5-1 flutter would have netted him \u00a3500.\n\nThe issue with those with close connections to the PM placing a bet on the election date comes with the individual having possible inside information that could give them an advantage.\n\nIt has not been confirmed whether Ms Saunders had any inside information when allegedly placing the bet.\n\nThe use of confidential information to gain unfair advantage when betting may constitute a criminal offence of cheating under section 42 of the Gambling Act.\n\nThose convicted face and unlimited fine or up to two years in jail.\n\nRead More Sunak aide investigated for placing \u00a3100 bet on July election days before PM set July 4 date\n\nThe investigation regarding Ms Saunders also comes as a police officer in Mr Sunak's close protection team has been suspended and arrested over alleged bets about the timing of the election, it was revealed on Wednesday.\n\nThe Metropolitan Police was contacted by the Gambling Commission last Friday and told the commission was investigating the activities of a member of Scotland Yard's Royalty and Specialist Protection (RaSP) command.\n\nThe police constable was removed from operational duties with immediate effect.\n\nA Met Police spokesperson said: 'We can confirm that on Friday, 14 June, the Met were contacted by the Gambling Commission who informed us that they were investigating alleged bets made by a Police Constable from the Met's Royalty and Specialist Protection Command, which were related to the timing of the General Election.\n\n'The matter was immediately referred to officers in the Met's Directorate of Professional Standards, who opened an investigation, and the officer was also removed from operational duties.\n\nThe issue with those with close connections to Rishi Sunak (pictured) placing a bet on the election date comes with the individual having possible inside information\n\nCraig Williams (pictured), Rishi Sunak 's parliamentary private secretary, is also being investigated after putting a \u00a3100 bet on the election being held in July, just days before the Prime Minister announced the July 4 vote\n\n'The officer was subsequently arrested on Monday 17 June on suspicion of misconduct in public office. He was taken into custody and bailed pending further enquiries. The matter has also been referred to the Independent Office for Police Conduct.\n\n'The Gambling Commission continues to lead the investigation into the alleged betting offences, and our investigation is running in parallel to that.'\n\nMr Williams, who is standing for re-election as MP in Montgomeryshire, bet on the election being held in July just three days before the announcement was made, The Guardian first reported.\n\nMeanwhile, the nation was surprised the election was going to be held in summer rather than autumn. He was taken into custody, bailed and has been removed from operational duties.\n\nLast week it emerged that Craig Williams, parliamentary private secretary to Sunak and hitherto Tory MP for Montgomeryshire, was also facing a Gambling Commission probe. He is alleged to have placed a \u00a3100 (Rs 10,600) bet at odds of 5/1 on a July polling date three days before the July 4 election was called. I should have thought through how it looks.\"\n\nA spokesperson for the Gambling Commission said: \"Currently the commission is investigating the possibility of offences concerning the date of the election. This is an ongoing investigation. {"uri": "2024-06-395989906", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "13:46:39", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T13:46:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T13:41:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.telegraphindia.com/world/british-prime-minister-rishi-sunaks-conservative-party-hit-with-election-date-betting-allegations/cid/2028510", "title": "British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's Conservative Party hit with election date betting allegations", "body": "The Metropolitan Police initially suspended an officer from Sunak's personal security detail and later arrested the individual on suspicion of misconduct in public office\n\nBritish Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's Conservative Party is facing a series of allegations on Thursday involving his bodyguard and aides over betting around the general election date, which is scheduled for July 4.\n\nThe Metropolitan Police initially suspended an officer from Sunak's personal security detail and later arrested the individual on suspicion of misconduct in public office.\n\nSoon after, it emerged that the UK's Gambling Commission was investigating several individuals linked to the governing Tories over allegedly betting on the timing of the election. While betting is legal in the UK, any bets placed with the advantage of insider information could fall within the purview of illegality.\n\n\"The matter was immediately referred to officers in the Met's Directorate of Professional Standards, who opened an investigation, and the officer was also removed from operational duties,\" the Met Police was quoted by the BBC as saying.\n\n\"The officer was subsequently arrested on Monday 17 June on suspicion of misconduct in public office. He was taken into custody and bailed pending further enquiries,\" the Met Police said.\n\nLast week, the 'Guardian' newspaper reported that Sunak's close parliamentary aide, Craig Williams, placed a GBP 100 bet with Ladbrokes at a five to one odds on a July election just three days before the British Indian leader had surprised the country with a summer election, as opposed to a widely expected autumn date later in the year. Williams, 39, is the Tory candidate for Montgomeryshire and Glyndwr in Wales. In a statement, he said his \"flutter\" on the election had prompted some \"routine inquiries\" and that he would \"fully cooperate with these\".\n\n\"I don't want it to be a distraction from the campaign. I should have thought through how it looks,\" he said.\n\nIt has since emerged that a second Conservative candidate, who is married to the party's Director of Campaigns - who would be expected to have knowledge of election matters, is also facing an investigation over allegedly betting on the timing of the general election. While Laura Saunders, the Tory candidate for Bristol North West, is reportedly among those being looked into by the Gambling Commission, her husband Tony Lee is said to have taken \"a leave of absence\" from his role.\n\n\"The Gambling Commission regulates gambling in the interests of consumers and the wider public,\" a commission spokesperson said.\n\n\"Currently, the commission is investigating the possibility of offences concerning the date of the election. This is an ongoing investigation, and the commission cannot provide any further details at this time. We are not confirming or denying the identity of any individuals involved in this investigation,\" the spokesperson said.\n\nUnder Section 42 of the UK's Gambling Act 2005, it is an offence to cheat at gambling or to do anything that allows someone else to cheat. The Conservative Party has said that the Gambling Commission being an independent regulatory body, it would not be \"proper to comment further, until any process is concluded\".\n\nHowever, the Opposition Labour Party has mounted pressure on Sunak, with leader Keir Starmer calling for Saunders to be suspended and said it is \"very telling\" that action had not been taken.\n\n\"If it was one of my candidates, they'd be gone and their feet would not have touched the floor,\" he said.\n\nSunak was asked about the first allegation involving Craig Williams on the sidelines of the G7 Summit in Italy last week, when he described it as \"very disappointing news\" but added that it \"wouldn't be appropriate for me to comment\" while the Gambling Commission's inquiries are ongoing.\n\nIt comes as the embattled Tories continue to be hammered in the pre-election surveys, with almost all analyses forecasting heavy losses for the governing party.", "source": {"uri": "telegraphindia.com", She is considering legal action against the BBC and any other publishers who infringe her privacy rights.\"\n\nNews of the investigation into Bristol North West candidate Ms Saunders emerged after the arrest of one of the Prime Minister's police protection officers and the previous revelation of a Gambling Commission investigation into his parliamentary aide Craig Williams over betting allegations.\n\nBetfair data appears to show a flurry of bets on a July poll placed on May 21, the day before Mr Sunak called the election, adding to concerns about political insiders gambling on its timing.\n\nFollowing a few months of people wagering a few pounds on a summer poll, betting spiked on the day prior to the announcement, including some in the hundreds of pounds at odds that would have delivered handsome profits in the thousands.\n\nA Conservative spokesman said: \"We have been contacted by the Gambling Commission about a small number of individuals.\n\n\"As the Gambling {"uri": "8185902262", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "20:13:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T20:13:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T20:12:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.thejournal.ie/rishi-sunak-protection-officer-arrested-alleged-bets-timing-uk-election-6414351-Jun2024/", "title": "Rishi Sunak's protection officer arrested over alleged bets on timing of UK election", "body": "The Metropolitan Police said the police constable was taken into custody and subsequently bailed pending further inquiries.\n\nA POLICE CONSTABLE working as part of British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's close protection team has been arrested and suspended over alleged bets about the timing of the UK general election.\n\nThe Metropolitan Police said the officer was taken into custody on Monday on suspicion of misconduct in a public office and has since been bailed pending further inquiries.\n\nIn a statement, the force said it was informed by the UK Gambling Commission that a police constable from the Met's Royalty and Specialist Protection Command was being investigated for alleged bets relating to the timing of the general election.\n\nPolice said the matter was immediately referred to the Met's Directorate of Professional Standards and the officer was also removed from operational duties.\n\n\"The officer was subsequently arrested on Monday 17 June on suspicion of misconduct in public office. He was taken into custody and bailed pending further enquiries. The matter has also been referred to the Independent Office for Police Conduct,\" the force continued.\n\nThe Gambling Commission is leading the investigation into the alleged betting offences, with the Met Police's probe running in parallel to it.\n\nIn a statement, the Gambling Commission said: \"Currently the commission is investigating the possibility of offences concerning the date of the election.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"This is an ongoing investigation, and the commission cannot provide any further details at this time.\"\n\nAccording to the Crown Prosecution Service's website, misconduct in a public office \"concerns serious wilful abuse or neglect of the power or responsibilities\".\n\nThose who can be accused of the offence include judges, bishops, MPs, civil servants, army officers, prison staff and police constables.\n\nDaisy Cooper, the deputy leader of the Liberal Democrats, has said that Sunak must call a Cabinet Office inquiry into \"what is shaping up to be yet another scandal at the heart of Government\".\n\n\"This stinks of yet more sleaze and answers are needed. An inquiry is needed to understand who knew what and when,\" she said.\n\nSunak previously said it was \"very disappointing\" that one of his closest aides and the current Conservative candidate for Montgomeryshire and Glyndwr in Wales, Craig Williams, had allegedly placed a bet on the date of the general election.\n\nWilliams, who was the Tory MP for Montgomery until the election was called, is alleged to have placed a \u00a3100 (\u20ac118) bet on a July polling day some three days before Sunak named the date as 4 July at a Ladbrokes in his constituency.\n\nHe previously said he had clearly made a \"huge error of judgment\" but refused to say whether he placed a bet on the basis of insider information.\n\nWith reporting from Press Association\n\nReaders like you are keeping these stories free for everyone... {"uri": "8186829343", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "10:34:38", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T10:34:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T10:34:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.bristolpost.co.uk/news/bristol-news/bristol-mp-candidate-investigated-over-9355900", "title": "Bristol candidate investigated over election-date bet allegation", "body": "A Conservative MP candidate in Bristol is being investigated by the Gambling Commission over allegations of a bet placed on the timing of the general election next month. Laura Saunders, standing for Bristol North West, is the second Tory MP hopeful facing an investigation following allegations last week that another Conservative candidate had placed a \u00a3100 bet on a July polling day, three days before the Prime Minister announced the date to the public.\n\nMs Saunders, who is married to the Tory Party's campaign chief Tony Lee, was the head of the international department at the Conservative Party, working with London embassies and the Tories' sister parties overseas and she had previously worked on organising campaign visits in the 2017 and 2019 elections. The BBC reports that Mr Lee was taking a leave of absence from his role at Tory HQ, with just two weeks until polling day.\n\nDetails of when the alleged bet was made and how much money was placed have not yet been made public. It comes after the arrest of one of Mr Sunak's police protection officers and a Gambling Commission investigation into his parliamentary aide Craig Williams over similar betting allegations.\n\nRead more:\n\nCabot Circus coffee shop to temporarily close down Major works on Temple Island in latest Bristol plans\n\nIn response to the latest allegations about Ms Saunders, a Conservative spokesman said: \"We have been contacted by the Gambling Commission about a small number of individuals. As the Gambling Commission is an independent body, it wouldn't be proper to comment further, until any process is concluded.\"\n\nHousing Secretary Mr Gove told the BBC: \"If people have used inside information to place bets, that is deeply wrong. What I can't do is sort of get too much into the detail of the case while an investigation is going on. But I can talk about the broad principle and you're absolutely right, it's reprehensible.\"\n\nThe Gambling Commission said: \"Currently the commission is investigating the possibility of offences concerning the date of the election. This is an ongoing investigation, and the commission cannot provide any further details at this time.\"\n\nMr Williams, who is standing for the Conservatives in Montgomeryshire and Glyndwr and who served as Mr Sunak's parliamentary private secretary, was under investigation after he \"put a flutter\" on when the election would take place. He is alleged to have placed a \u00a3100 bet on a July polling day some three days before Mr Sunak named the date as July 4, at a Ladbrokes in his constituency.\n\nHe previously said he had clearly made a \"huge error of judgment\" but refused to say whether he placed a bet on the basis of insider information. Prime Minister Rishi Sunak previously said it was \"very disappointing\" that Mr Williams had allegedly placed a bet on the date of the general election.\n\nOn Wednesday, July 19, the Metropolitan Police said they were informed by the Gambling Commission that a police constable from the force's Royalty and Specialist Protection Command was being investigated over alleged betting.\n\nThe police officer, who has been removed from operational duties, was bailed pending further inquiries after they were taken into custody on Monday on suspicion of misconduct in a public office. The matter has been referred to the Independent Office for Police Conduct (IOPC), which said it will \"make a decision on the level of IOPC involvement in due course\".\n\nWant the latest Bristol breaking news and top stories first? Command was being investigated over the alleged bets.\n\nPolice said the matter was immediately referred to the Met's Directorate of Professional Standards and the officer was also removed from operational duties.\n\nThe matter has been referred to the Independent Office for Police Conduct (IOPC), who said they will \"make a decision on the level of IOPC involvement in due course\".\n\nThe Gambling Commission is leading the investigation into the alleged betting offences, which is running parallel to the Met's probe.\n\nIn a statement, the Gambling Commission said: \"Currently the time.\"\n\nAccording to the Crown Prosecution Service's website, misconduct in a public office \"concerns serious wilful abuse or neglect of the power or responsibilities\".\n\nThose who can be accused of the offence include judges, bishops, MPs, civil servants, army officers, prison staff and police constables.\n\nRishi Sunak previously said it was \"very disappointing\" that one of his She is considering legal action against the BBC and any other publishers who infringe her privacy rights.\"\n\nNews of the investigation into Bristol North West candidate Ms Saunders emerged after the arrest of one of the Prime Minister's police protection officers and the previous revelation of a Gambling Commission investigation into his parliamentary aide Craig Williams over betting allegations.\n\nBetfair data appears to show a flurry of bets on a July poll placed on May 21, the day before Mr Sunak called the election, adding to concerns about political insiders gambling on its timing.\n\nFollowing a few months of people wagering a few pounds on a summer poll, betting spiked on the day prior to the announcement, including some in the hundreds of pounds at odds that would have delivered handsome profits in the thousands.\n\nCabinet minister Michael Gove admitted the situation \"doesn't look great\" for the Tories.\n\nA Conservative spokesman said: \"We have been contacted by the Gambling Commission about a small number of individuals.\n\n\"As the Gambling Commission is an independent body, it wouldn't be proper to comment further, until any process is concluded.\"\n\nThe Gambling Commission said: \"Currently, the commission is investigating the possibility of offences concerning the date of the election.\n\n\"This is an ongoing investigation, and the commission cannot provide any further details at this time.\n\n\"We are not confirming or denying the identity of any individuals involved in this investigation.\"\n\nLabour and the Liberal Democrats called for the Tories to suspend both Ms Saunders and Mr Williams.\n\nSir Keir Starmer said: \"If it was one of my candidates, they'd be gone and their feet would not have touched the floor.\"\n\nOn Wednesday, the Metropolitan Police said they were informed by the Gambling Commission that a police constable from the force's Royalty and Specialist Protection Command was being investigated over the alleged bets.\n\nThe police officer, who has been removed from operational duties, was bailed pending further inquiries after they were taken into custody on Monday on suspicion {"uri": "2024-06-395749508", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "10:29:24", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T10:29:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T09:23:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.itv.com/news/westcountry/2024-06-20/tory-candidate-being-investigated-over-general-election-bet", "title": "Bristol Tory candidate faces investigation into election bets", "body": "The Conservative candidate for Bristol North West, Laura Saunders is facing a Gambling Commission investigation into alleged betting offences.\n\nMs Saunders is married to Tony Lee, the Conservative Party's director of campaigning, the BBC reported.\n\nShe was the head of the international department at the Conservative Party, working with London embassies and the Tories' sister parties overseas.\n\nMs Saunders had previously worked on organising campaign visits in the 2017 and 2019 elections.\n\nNews of the investigation followed the arrest of one of Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's police protection officers and a Gambling Commission investigation into his parliamentary aide Craig Williams over betting allegations.\n\nIn response to the latest allegations about Bristol North West candidate Ms Saunders, a Conservative spokesperson said: \"We have been contacted by the Gambling Commission about a small number of individuals.\n\n\"As the Gambling Commission is an independent body, it wouldn't be proper to comment further, until any process is concluded.\"\n\nThe Gambling Commission said: \"Currently the commission is investigating the possibility of offences concerning the date of the election.\n\n\"This is an ongoing investigation, and the commission cannot provide any further details at this time.\"\n\nThe parliamentary candidates for Bristol North West are:\n\nHousing Secretary Michael Gove told the BBC: \"If people have used inside information to place bets, that is deeply wrong.\n\n\"What I can't do is sort of get too much into the detail of the case while an investigation is going on.\n\n\"But I can talk about the broad principle and you're absolutely right, it's reprehensible.\"\n\nCabinet Minister Michael Gove told ITV News betting on the date of the General Election would be 'reprehensible'.\n\nLiberal Democrats deputy leader Daisy Cooper said: \"Rishi Sunak must find his backbone and suspend Laura Saunders from the Conservative party whilst this investigation is ongoing.\n\n\"It would be an utter disgrace if Conservative politicians were shown to be more focused on turning a quick buck rather than the needs of the country.\n\n\"The Conservative party has proven itself utterly unfit for office. Voters are sick to the back teeth of this endless carousel of chaos, sleaze and scandal.\n\n\"People across the country are crying out for change and that is why in many areas they are backing the Liberal Democrats to get a strong local champion that will take their issues right to the heart of Parliament and not take them for granted any longer.\"\n\nIt emerged last week that Craig Williams, who served as Mr Sunak's parliamentary private secretary and is the Conservative candidate for Montgomeryshire and Glyndwr, was under investigation after he \"put a flutter\" on when the election would take place.\n\nOn Wednesday the Metropolitan Police said they were informed by the Gambling Commission that a police constable from the force's Royalty and Specialist Protection Command was being investigated over the alleged bets.\n\nThe police officer, who has been removed from operational duties, was bailed pending further inquiries after they were taken into custody on Monday on suspicion of misconduct in a public office.\n\nThe matter has been referred to the Independent Office for Police Conduct (IOPC), which said it will \"make a decision on the level of IOPC involvement in due course\".\n\nMr Sunak previously said it was \"very disappointing\" that Mr Williams had allegedly placed a bet on the date of the General Election.\n\nCraig Williams, who was the Tory MP for Montgomery until the election was called and is the party's candidate for Montgomeryshire and Glyndwr, is alleged to have placed a \u00a3100 bet on a July polling day some three days before Mr Sunak named the date as July 4, at a Ladbrokes in his constituency.\n\nHe previously said he had clearly made a \"huge error of judgment\" but refused to say whether he placed a bet on the basis of insider information.\n\nElsewhere on Thursday, Mr Sunak will join three other party leaders in taking part in a BBC Question Time special.\n\nThe two-hour programme will see each leader appear one by one to face questions from the audience.\n\nLabour's Sir Keir Starmer will also take part along with Scotland's First Minister John Swinney for the SNP and Sir Ed Davey for the Liberal Democrats.\n\nThe latest televised election event comes after YouGov said the Conservatives are projected to slump to their \"lowest seat tally in the party's almost 200-year history\" at the election.\n\nYouGov said its latest study projects Labour to secure 425 seats, the Tories 108, the Liberal Democrats 67, the SNP 20, Reform UK five, Plaid Cymru four and the Green Party two.\n\nIt noted such a scenario would hand Sir Keir a 200-seat majority while it added Reform UK leader Nigel Farage is \"likely\" to win in Clacton.\n\nYouGov used a technique known as multi-level regression and post-stratification (MRP) to model the outcome of the election in every constituency across Britain.\n\nIt said the estimated seat projections were based on modelled responses from 36,161 adults in England and Wales and 3,818 Although wagering is permitted in the UK, wagers made with the benefit of insider knowledge may be prohibited.\n\n\"The matter was immediately referred to officers in the Met's Directorate of Professional Standards, who opened an investigation, and the officer was also removed from operational duties,\" the Met Police was quoted by the BBC as saying.\n\n\"The officer was subsequently arrested on Monday 17 June on suspicion of misconduct in public office. He was taken into custody and bailed pending further enquiries,\" the Met Police said.\n\nThree days before Sunak shocked the nation by calling a summer election rather than the more anticipated fall date later in the year, Sunak's close parliamentary aide Craig Williams placed a GBP 100 bet with Ladbrokes at a five to one odds. This information was reported by the newspaper The Guardian last week.\n\nThe 39-year-old Williams is the Tory nominee for Glyndwr in Wales and Montgomeryshire. He said he would \"fully cooperate with these\" and that his \"flutter\" on the election had triggered some \"routine inquiries\" in a statement.\n\n\"I don't want it to be a distraction from the campaign. I should have thought through how it looks,\" he said.\n\nSince then, it has come to light that a second Conservative candidate is also under investigation for allegedly placing bets on the general election's schedule. {"uri": "8186916796", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "11:29:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T11:29:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T11:27:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/politics/article/2024/jun/20/gambling-watchdog-looks-into-second-tory-candidate-over-alleged-election-bet-laura-saunders", "title": "Gambling watchdog looks into second Tory candidate over alleged election bet", "body": "Party urged to suspend Laura Saunders, whose husband - the party's director of campaigns - is also reportedly being looked at\n\nThe Gambling Commission is looking into a second Conservative candidate over an alleged bet on the timing of the general election.\n\nLaura Saunders, the party's candidate in Bristol North West, is married to Tony Lee, the Conservative party's director of campaigns.\n\nLee took leave of absence on Wednesday.\n\nA Conservative spokesperson said: \"The director of campaigning took a leave of absence from CCHQ yesterday.\"\n\nMinutes later the BBC reported that Lee was also being looked into by the commission.\n\nIt is not known how much money was allegedly staked or whether any bet was made personally.\n\nLast week the Guardian revealed that Rishi Sunak's closest parliamentary aide, Craig Williams, placed a \u00a3100 bet with Ladbrokes at 5/1 on a July poll, three days before the prime minister announced the date.\n\nWilliams, 39, is the Tory candidate for Montgomeryshire and Glynd\u0175r in mid-Wales. He had a majority of 12,000 before the boundary change.\n\nIn the wake of the revelation the Guardian also revealed that the Gambling Commission asked bookmakers to trawl through all substantial bets placed on a July election.\n\nThe watchdog wrote to all licensed bookmakers requesting information on anyone who stood to gain more than \u00a3199 by betting on a July election in the UK.\n\nA Conservative party spokesperson told the BBC: \"We have been contacted by the Gambling Commission about a small number of individuals. As the Gambling Commission is an independent body, it wouldn't be proper to comment further, until any process is concluded.\"\n\nKeir Starmer called for the Conservatives to suspend Saunders. \"This candidate should be suspended and it's very telling that Rishi Sunak has not already done that.\n\n\"If it was one of my candidates, they'd be gone and their feet would not have touched the floor.\"\n\nSeparately, one of Rishi Sunak's close protection officers has been arrested over alleged bets about the timing of the election.\n\nThe officer was arrested on Monday on suspicion of misconduct in public office, the Metropolitan police said.\n\nThe Metropolitan police said they were contacted last Friday by the Gambling Commission, which informed the force that it was looking into alleged bets related to the timing of an election by a constable from the Met's royalty and specialist protection command.\n\n\"The matter was immediately referred to officers in the Met's directorate of professional standards, who opened an investigation, and the officer was also removed from operational duties,\" the force said.\n\nThe matter has also been referred to the Independent Office for Police Conduct (IOPC), the watchdog responsible for overseeing the system for handling complaints made against police forces in England and Wales.\n\nThe Met added: \"The Gambling Commission continues to lead the investigation into the alleged betting offences, and our investigation is running in parallel to that.\"\n\nLabour's campaign chief, Pat McFadden, has written to Sunak urging the Conservatives to withdraw support from Saunders and Williams while they are being looked into.\n\nIn a letter to the prime minister, McFadden said: \"Can I ask you very simply why you think that a serving police officer should be suspended from his role, because of allegations that he made a bet based on inside information, while the two colleagues of yours who so far stand accused of the same offence - Craig Williams, your PPS, and Laura Saunders, a member of your CCHQ staff and partner of your campaigns director - are still being allowed to stand as Tory candidates in the election on 4 July?.\"\n\nHe added: \"This looks as though there is one rule for members of the Tory party, and another rule for everyone else, specifically on this occasion a serving police officer.\"\n\nMcFadden said if it emerged that Williams, Saunders and any other candidate had placed bets on the timing of the election they should be suspended.", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", "dataType": "news", protection team arrested over alleged election bets", "body": "The Metropolitan Police said the officer was taken into custody on Monday on suspicion of misconduct in a public office and has since been bailed pending further inquiries.\n\nIn a statement, the force said it was informed by the Gambling Commission that a police constable from the Met's Royalty and Specialist Protection Command was being investigated over the alleged bets.\n\nPolice said the matter was immediately referred to the Met's Directorate of Professional Standards and the officer was also removed from operational duties.\n\nThe matter has been referred to the Independent Office for Police Conduct (IOPC), who said they will \"make a decision on the level of IOPC involvement in due course\".\n\nThe Gambling Commission is leading the investigation into the alleged betting offences, which is running parallel to the Met's probe.\n\nIn a statement, the Gambling Commission said: \"Currently the commission is investigating the possibility of offences concerning the date of the election.\n\n\"This is an ongoing investigation, and the commission cannot provide any further details at this time.\"\n\nAccording to the Crown Prosecution Service's website, misconduct in a public office \"concerns serious wilful abuse or neglect of the power or responsibilities\".\n\nThose who can be accused of the offence include judges, bishops, MPs, civil servants, army officers, prison staff and police constables.\n\nLiberal Democrats deputy leader Daisy Cooper said: \"Rishi Sunak must call a Cabinet Office inquiry into what is shaping up to be yet another scandal at the heart of Government.\n\n\"This stinks of yet more sleaze and answers are needed. takes leave of absence amid election betting...", "body": "Rishi Sunak's election campaign has been thrown into fresh turmoil over allegations of betting on the date of the General Election.\n\nWith just two weeks until polling day, the Conservatives' director of campaigning Tony Lee took a leave of absence amid reports both he and his would-be MP wife Laura Saunders are being investigated by the Gambling Commission.\n\nMs Saunders and Mr Lee are the latest people with links to the Tory party or No 10 caught up in allegations about betting on the date of the July 4 contest.\n\nCabinet minister Michael Gove admitted the situation \"doesn't look great\" for the Conservatives.\n\nNews of the investigation into Bristol North West candidate Ms Saunders emerged after the arrest of one of the Prime Minister's police protection officers and the previous revelation of a Gambling Commission investigation into his parliamentary aide Craig Williams over betting allegations.\n\nA Conservative spokesman said: \"We have been contacted by the Gambling Commission about a small number of individuals.\n\n\"As the Gambling Commission is an independent body, it wouldn't be proper to comment further, until any process is concluded.\"\n\nThe Gambling Commission said: \"Currently the commission is investigating the possibility of offences concerning the date of the election.\n\n\"This is an ongoing investigation, and the commission cannot provide any further details at this time.\n\n\"We are not confirming or denying the identity of any individuals involved in this investigation.\"\n\nOn the Tory campaign battle bus in London, Mr Gove told broadcasters: \"Obviously, it doesn't look great. And, obviously, the conclusions lots of people are drawing are not at all great.\n\n\"But I don't know all the facts at the moment. I'd be loath to condemn without there being an investigation that's been concluded.\"\n\nMr Sunak's parliamentary aide Mr Williams, who is standing in Montgomeryshire and Glyndwr, is also under investigation over a bet.\n\nMr Gove said: \"The Gambling Commission are looking at Craig and also looking at Laura, and we'll see what the conclusions are.\"\n\nThe BBC reported that the gambling regulator was also looking into Mr Lee.\n\nLabour and the Liberal Democrats called for the Tories to suspend both Ms Saunders and Mr Williams.\n\nSir Keir Starmer said: \"If it was one of my candidates, they'd be gone and their feet would not have touched the floor.\"\n\nOn Wednesday the Metropolitan Police said they were informed by the Gambling Commission that a police constable from the force's Royalty and Specialist Protection Command was being investigated over the alleged bets.\n\nThe police officer, who has been removed from operational duties, was bailed pending further inquiries after they were taken into custody on Monday on suspicion of misconduct in a public office.\n\nThe matter has been referred to the Independent Office for Police Conduct (IOPC), which said it will \"make a decision on the level of IOPC involvement in due course\".\n\nCraig Williams, who is facing a Gambling Commission probe after he 'put a flutter\u00b4 on when the General Election would take place (UK Parliament/PA)\n\nThe revelations about Mr Williams emerged last week, and he admitted it was a \"huge error of judgment\" to have a \"flutter\" on the election.\n\nLabour's campaign co-ordinator Pat McFadden has written to the Prime Minister calling for the candidates' suspension and questioning \"how wide this scandal goes\".\n\nHe said that given the police officer had been removed from their duties, \"surely you can understand that - yet again - this looks as though there is one rule for members of the Tory party, and another rule for everyone else\".\n\n\"If you can see how wrong that is, will you now at the very least remove your support for Mr Williams and Ms Saunders as Conservative election candidates?\n\n\"The other major question to be addressed is how wide this scandal goes.\n\n\"If some of your most senior colleagues felt they had carte blanche to misuse the inside information they had on the election in order to make a profit, we must ask how many {"uri": "8187483553", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:44:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:44:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:41:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://news.sky.com/story/more-names-expected-to-come-out-in-betting-scandal-as-tory-candidate-says-she-will-fully-cooperate-13155879", "title": "More names expected to come out in betting scandal - as Tory candidate says she will 'fully cooperate'", "body": "More political figures are being looked into over bets placed on the timing of the general election, a gambling industry source has told Sky News.\n\nTwo Tory candidates are already being investigated by the Gambling Commission over alleged wagers placed on the date of the 4 July contest.\n\nAn industry source told Sky News that \"more names\" are being looked at, though police \"are not involved\".\n\nFollow live: Tory candidate 'considers legal action'\n\nIt risks throwing Rishi Sunak's campaign into further turmoil after it emerged on Thursday that Laura Saunders, the Tory candidate for Bristol North West, is being looked into by the watchdog.\n\nShe has worked for the party since 2015 and is married to the Conservative Party's director of campaigns, Tony Lee.\n\nMr Lee \"took a leave of absence\" from his role on Wednesday night, a Conservative Party spokesman told Sky News.\n\nIt is not known how much money Ms Saunders placed or when the bet was made.\n\nIn a statement on Thursday afternoon, she said she will be \"cooperating with the Gambling Commission\" investigation.\n\nShe also said she is considering \"legal action against the BBC\" claiming their initial story was \"premature\" and \"in breach of her privacy rights\".\n\nThe full statement, released by Ms Saunders' solicitor, said: \"As the Conservative Party has already stated investigations are ongoing.\n\n\"Ms Saunders will be co-operating with the Gambling Commission and has nothing further to add.\n\n\"It is inappropriate to conduct any investigation of this kind via the media, and doing so risks jeopardising the work of the Gambling Commission and the integrity of its investigation.\n\n\"The publication of the BBC's story is premature and is a clear infringement of Ms Saunders' privacy rights. She is considering legal action against the BBC and any other publishers who infringe her privacy rights.\"\n\nThe incident comes a week after the prime minister's close parliamentary aide Craig Williams, the Tory candidate in Montgomeryshire and Glyndwr, was revealed to have placed a bet on a July election date three days before the prime minister announced it.\n\nThe prime minister's close protection officer has been arrested and suspended over alleged bets about the timing of the election.\n\nLabour Party campaign sources told Sky News they noticed the odds on a July election narrow the day before Mr Sunak announced it on 22 May.\n\nLevelling Up Secretary Michael Gove, who is stepping down after 19 years as an MP, told Sky News' Breakfast with Kay Burley: \"It's deeply disappointing and upsetting.\n\n\"But I have to say it's the exception rather than the rule.\"\n\nHe later said the whole episode is \"deeply regrettable\", and added: \"I can tell you how the world will think it looks, which is not great.\"\n\nIn the hours after it was revealed Ms Saunders' bet was being looked into, the Conservatives deleted a social media post they had put up the previous day featuring a video of a roulette wheel and the caption: \"If you bet on Labour, you can never win.\"\n\nA Conservative spokesman told Sky News: \"We have been contacted by the Gambling Commission about a small number of individuals.\n\n\"As the Gambling Commission is an independent body, it wouldn't be proper to comment further, until any process is concluded.\"\n\nA Gambling Commission spokesman told Sky News: \"The Gambling Commission regulates gambling in the interests of consumers and the wider public.\n\n\"Currently, the commission is investigating the possibility of offences concerning the date of the election. This is an ongoing investigation, and the commission cannot provide any further details at this time.\n\n\"We are not confirming or denying the identity of any individuals involved in this investigation.\"\n\nLabour leader Sir Keir Starmer called for Ms Saunders to be suspended and said it is \"very telling\" Mr Sunak has not already done so.\n\n\"If it was one of my candidates, they'd be gone and their feet would not have touched the floor,\" he added.\n\nThe officer who has been arrested is a member of the Met's Royalty and Specialist Protection (RaSP) Command, which provides personal close protection to ministerial VIPs and members of the Royal Family.\n\nSky News understands several bets were placed by the officer, with at least one of them being a three-figure sum.\n\nThe Met Police said the matter was immediately referred on 14 June to officers in the force's directorate of professional standards, who opened an investigation. The officer was also removed from operational duties.\n\nIn a statement, the Met said: \"The officer was subsequently arrested on Monday 17 June on suspicion of misconduct in public office. He was taken into custody and bailed pending further enquiries.\"\n\nMr Sunak said he was \"disappointed\" about Mr Williams after it emerged last week that he had bet on a July election.\n\n\ud83d\udc49 Tap here to follow Politics at Jack and Sam's wherever you get your podcasts \ud83d\udc48\n\nMr Williams, who was Mr Sunak's parliamentary private secretary (PPS), is facing an investigation after he \"put a flutter on the general election\" three days before the 4 July date was announced.\n\nThe odds at the time were 5/1 and he placed \u00a3100 on, which would have led to a \u00a3500 payout.\n\nIn a statement, he said his \"flutter\" on the election had prompted some \"routine inquiries\" and that he would \"fully co-operate with these\".\n\n\"I don't want it to be a distraction from the campaign.
