{"uri": "2024-06-396130339", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "15:47:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T15:47:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T15:41:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4549019634723663, "url": "https://www.telegraph.co.uk/politics/2024/06/20/huge-spike-in-bets-on-day-before-sunak-announced-election/", "title": "Huge spike in bets on day before Sunak announced election", "body": "Analysis of data provided by bookmakers shows almost all the wagers on July poll were made in a few hours on May 21\n\nA flood of bets were placed on a July election on the day before one was announced by Rishi Sunak, data reveals.\n\nAnalysis of data provided by bookmakers showed that almost all the wagers on a July poll - totalling thousands of pounds - were made in a few hours on May 21.\n\nAt just after 5.15pm the next day, Mr Sunak announced the surprise summer election, having previously been widely expected to call a contest in the autumn.\n\nSeveral senior Conservatives are facing investigations by the gambling watchdog over allegations that they had placed bets on the July date before it was public.\n\nThe analysis of figures from Betfair, the world's largest online betting exchange, showed that almost \u00a36,000 was placed in bets on a July 4 election in the flurry of activity on May 21.\n\nAt that point, a summer poll was still considered an outside chance, with odds suggesting there was less than a 25 per cent chance.\n\nUntil then, wagers on July 4 had come in dribs and drabs, with the daily total rarely exceeding \u00a3500, suggesting ordinary punters taking a flutter.\n\nSeparate data provided by Smarkets, another betting exchange, painted a similar picture. It showed that until May 21, the vast majority of bets - typically making up more than four in five - were being placed on the expected autumn election.\n\nBut on May 21 there was a huge surge in wagers, with more than 90 per cent of all those placed on that day put on July 4.\n\nThe revelations will pile further pressure on the Tories after it emerged a number of top figures are facing gambling watchdog investigations.\n\nThey include Craig Williams, Mr Sunak's parliamentary private secretary, who reportedly wagered \u00a3100 on the date of the election just three days before it was called.\n\nMr Williams has admitted he had a \"flutter\" on the election date a few weeks ago, and has apologised for a \"huge error of judgment\".\n\nOn Thursday, the BBC reported that Laura Saunders, a Tory parliamentary candidate, was also being investigated by the Gambling Commission over an election bet.\n\nShe is the wife of Tony Lee, the Conservative Party's director of campaigning, who is also being looked at by the commission and has taken a \"leave of absence\" from his post following the revelations.\n\nA police officer working in Mr Sunak's close protection team has been The statement followed news reports that the Gambling Commission was looking into allegations of improper betting by Lee and his wife Laura Saunders, a candidate for parliament in Bristol. British bookmakers allow bets on politics, and the timing of an election is a popular bet. But placing bets with insider knowledge is a crime.\n\nNot in the 'Hunt'?\n\nMeanwhile, British finance minister Jeremy Hunt on Thursday said it would be \"very tough\" for the Conservatives to win after opinion polls showed a landslide win for the opposition Labour Party.\n\nAsked at a Times newspaper event whether the Conservatives could win the election, Hunt said: \"It's going to be very tough. \"I don't think any of us would pretend that is the most likely outcome. We can certainly do a lot better than the polls are suggesting and we are working very hard to do so.\"\n\nA separate poll predicted Sunak could become the first British PM in history to lose his own seat in a national election. {"uri": "2024-06-396164228", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "16:20:45", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T16:20:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T16:08:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4392156898975372, "url": "https://www.politico.eu/newsletter/london-playbook/london-playbook-pm-timing-is-everything/", "title": "London Playbook PM: Timing is everything", "body": "-- Rishi Sunak is preparing for a TV showdown with the public amid a Conservative gambling storm that's seen a senior CCHQ campaign boss go on leave.\n\n-- The PM is under pressure to suspend candidates facing allegations of betting on the election date with inside knowledge.\n\n-- The Bank of England held interest rates and set the stage for an August cut ... prompting more questions about the July election decision.\n\n-- A dispatch from the Playbook election tour sparked a massive scaremongering row about the green belt.\n\n-- A former top aide to Canadian PM Stephen Harper has some advice for the Tories, in light of the obsession about the 1993 election in Canada.\n\nTOP OF THE NEWSLIST\n\nIN POLITICS, TIMING IS EVERYTHING: Rishi Sunak is preparing for a harrowing showdown with the public tonight under the shadow of a massive election scandal -- details of which will be beamed into millions of homes. It could get ... pretty rough.\n\nNo really, timing is everything: The revelation from BBC Pol Ed Chris Mason this morning that a second Conservative candidate who allegedly placed a bet on the timing of the election is married to the *checks notes* CCHQ director of campaigns will no doubt come up during the Beeb's Question Time special, set to air from 8 p.m.\n\nThe format: The show will revolve around questions from the audience to the four main party leaders, with Sunak at the end. But if a member of the public fails to ask the PM about the gambling thing, there's zero chance host Fiona Bruce will let it slide. We'll be covering every beat and doing snap analysis on our election live blog.\n\nOut of the shadows: It will be the first time Sunak has had to respond to the scandal since a bunch of new twists. He's been behind closed doors for more than 24-hours preparing for the event.\n\nAnd that means: Whatever line he takes on the issue will be a vital news moment, clipped up, written up and shared far and wide on social media.\n\nSorry did we mention that timing is everything? It also means members of the public who tune in at 8 p.m. (that's prime time TV) and who might not have heard about the scandal, now will do. The ITV debate between Sunak and Keir Starmer earlier in the campaign attracted average viewing figures of almost 5 million, don't forget. A good number of viewers tonight should be well across it already, though, after the BBC News app push-alerted its scoop this morning, ensuring millions read about Bristol North West candidate Laura Saunders being probed by the Gambling Commission.\n\nNo, that is indeed not good: With two weeks to go until polling day, and with postal votes stuffing themselves into letterboxes right now, the Conservatives announced late morning Lee had taken a leave of absence. Which means Rishi Sunak has lost a senior campaign director in the middle of an election campaign, in which the Tories are fighting to avoid oblivion. \"For f*ck's sake,\" one Conservative minister said when Playbook PM mentioned Lee's departure. \"That is not good.\"\n\nBetting man? The fate of Saunders and Lee should center on the moment the alleged bets were placed -- details are still to be made public. One of Lee's allies suggested he might not have known the timing of the election date until it was called, seeing as the circle of knowledge around it was so tight, and that it would not be the \"cautious\" campaigner's style to take such a risk even if he was aware.\n\nFilling the void: It's now been almost 24 hours since Lee took his leave of absence. The lack of front foot from the Tories on all this allowed Lib Dem leader Ed Davey to urge the authorities to \"come down heavily on the people who look like they've acted illegally and immorally.\"\n\nLabour twists the knife: The Tories appear to be making the problem worse for themselves with hesitation over Saunders' fate. \"If it was one of my candidates, they would be gone and their feet would not have touched the floor,\" Keir Starmer said in a national broadcast interview. Labour campaign co-ordinator Pat McFadden twisted the knife with a punchy letter about the failure to act on candidates, despite fast action against Sunak's close protection officer over similar allegations. Housing Secretary Michael Gove said on the morning round that the situation was \"regrettable\" but that it's right that those involved get the \"benefit of whatever doubt there is.\"\n\nNot just the opposition: Angry Conservatives are also filling the void. Conservative former leader Iain Duncan Smith told the News Agents podcast this afternoon those being investigated are \"stupid and venal\" and \"whatever happens to them wouldn't be hard enough in my book.\" Nigel Farage got in on the act too, branding it \"corruption.\"\n\nSo, yeah, in politics timing is everything: This scandal has grown in power because it has dripped out over time. It was a week ago that Sunak's top MP aide Craig Williams admitted placing his own bet on the election date days before it was called -- without being clear whether he knew about the plan at the time or not. Last night the arrest and suspension of the police officer drove the issue up the news agenda again. And then a succession of bombshells on a quiet morning in the campaign mean there's now real momentum to this story.\n\nTwo years feels like ages ago: Sunak, of course, promised on the steps of Downing Street to lead a government with \"integrity, professionalism, and accountability at every level.\" That came after the endless abuses of the Boris Johnson era, as well as the Liz Truss financial stinkbomb. That's all fed public mistrust in politics, and a fresh scandal two weeks before the election, dredging it all back up, is the last thing the PM needs. Our Rosa Prince has more on that theme here.\n\nWhoops: One excellent irony of all this is that bets being placed in the run-up to the election announcement, and a subsequent surge in the markets, might have tipped Labour mastermind Morgan McSweeney off that a summer poll was coming -- helping the opposition avoid an ambush. See here from Gabriel Pogrund. And the FT's Chris Cook has been digging into the \"unusual\" betting data.\n\nThe internet never forgets: Another great irony is that the Tories shared a gambling themed attack ad against Labour just ... last night. It has now been deleted, of course.\n\nThanks, Andrew Bailey: In another timing headache for Sunak, the Bank of England announced at noon it will keep interest rates the same, despite inflation hitting the target 2 percent this week. Tories had been hoping for a cut during the election campaign, to feed into the narrative about turning some kind of corner. See former Downing Street aide Guto Harri making the case on Good Morning Britain. But that hope didn't deliver, and it could in fact be a Starmer government that gets to claim credit in August for the first interest rate reduction since 2020.\n\nOkay one more time, we promise, but timing really is everything: That has sparked off a fresh round of questioning about what exactly possessed Sunak to call the election now, rather than waiting until *after* interest rates had been reduced, as well as *after* the first deportation flight to Rwanda might have taken off. One Conservative aide said: \"These continued issues show how foolish the PM was to call an election for July.\"\n\nNow read this: HuffPost's Kevin Schofield has a piece asking whether the Tories are running \"the worst general election campaign of all time,\" which includes this glorious quote from a senior Conservative: \"If I woke up on the morning of July 5 to find out that it had been an elaborate performance art piece instead of a genuine campaign, I would not be surprised.\" Add to the list moving resources once more to ultra safe seats, including the PM's own, as Bloomberg's Alex Wickham revealed this morning.\n\n**Please complete this quick survey to help us understand the political and policy issues you most care about and how you use this information professionally. Your participation is greatly appreciated and will only take a few minutes.**\n\nDRIVETIME DEBRIEF\n\nTODAY IN SCAREMONGERING: The Tories want to talk about the green belt and Labour wants to talk about Liz Truss -- both based on campaign slips from their opponents. Michael Gove and Rishi Sunak were straight out the blocks on Radio 4 and Twitter this morning, quoting our morning Playbook tour line from a Labour aide about not caring \"if we flatten the whole green belt; we just need more houses.\" Gove said it was an example of \"vibes politics with a nasty edge\" while the PM said it was \"good to finally get Labour's real views on Britain's green belt.\"\n\nBut but but: Speaking to hacks on the campaign trail, Keir Starmer insisted it was not Labour policy and that the quote did not come from Labour officials. POLITICO's Stefan Boscia, who reported the line as part of his tour dispatch from Aylesbury, stands by his reporting, of course. More on our liveblog.\n\nAnd on the Labour attack side ... the opposition pounced on comments from Chancellor Jeremy Hunt at the Times CEO summit this morning that it was unfair to claim the Liz Truss maxi-budget caused \"sustained economic scarring.\" A Labour spokesperson said the comments were \"insulting to the millions of people\" whose mortgages have gone up, and pointed to costings holes in the Conservative manifesto. (Not that the Labour manifesto is much better.)\n\nACTUAL FEAR: It's badgers who have reason to be frightened, with the i's Arj Singh reporting a Labout government would continue their cull.\n\nHEALTHY DEBATE: Health Secretary Victoria Atkins blasted junior doctors, who are still planning to strike during the election campaign, in a letter posted to Twitter. She noted the government can't actually make offers to settle the ongoing dispute until the election is done, after the British Medical Association offered the prime minister a final chance to make a deal before action late next week.\n\nHealth scare: The Tories meanwhile seized on new figures in Wales showing its NHS waiting lists (under a Labour administration) hitting a new record high of 775,031 in April. \"This is what happens when Labour are in power without a plan, and with unchecked power, Keir Starmer would do exactly the same in England,\" a Conservative spokesperson said. Bear in mind that's what the Conservatives have done in England too.\n\nDANCING AROUND THE MAPLE: With a Conservative wipeout looking likely, numerous comparisons have been made with Canada in 1993, when the Progressive Conservatives fell from 156 seats to just two -- in part due to a surging populist movement named ... Reform. In truth, the comparisons don't quite work, because Reform was a regional party based on grievances about specific industrial policies, and was one half of a geographic sandwich that squeezed the conservatives from two sides.\n\nNevertheless: The Conservatives in Britain could learn something from the 1993 defeat, according to Andrew MacDougall, a former top aide to Canadian PM Stephen Harper: how to build back afterwards. Harper was a senior figure in the Reform movement that helped decimate the Progressive Conservatives but later merged with them, before entering government in 2006 as leader of the Conservative Party of Canada.\n\nSo ... what's the advice? \"The Conservatives have to get back to ideas,\" MacDougall told Playbook PM, and avoid the siren calls of Nigel Farage. \"You're never going to out-rage or out-media Farage. But ultimately, his bravado and persona don't fix problems,\" MacDougall said. Conservative minister Steve Baker agreed that Farage should be kept out, telling the Sun he \"toxifies\" debates.\n\nFixing things: MacDougall argued the modern Conservatives in Canada built public support by focusing on practical solutions to internal national problems, rather than pointing blame outside. Having a fight about who can out-right-wing each other post-Rishi Sunak won't work, he said, arguing the Tories will need to \"get out of vibe mode,\" take a step back from reactive media soundbites and think deeper.\n\nProblem is: The chance of a return straight to solution politics is slim, with the Tories poised to plunge into civil war in the wake of the election and with Farage stoking the flames. But MacDougall notes the Tories will still have a campaign structure and more practical mechanics than Reform will, and a quick return to pragmatic politics could turn things back around before the next election. \"Nothing concentrates the mind like the prospect of a hanging,\" he said. \"Well, that hanging is here.\"\n\nFARAGE MARCHES ON: More people want Reform to become the official opposition than the Conservatives if Labour wins the election, according to research from Redfield and Wilton. Some 27 percent of poll respondents picked Reform as their preferred opposition, compared with 22 percent who said the Conservatives and 21 percent who said the Lib Dems. Shunning those Farage siren calls is going to be difficult.\n\nMore amusing public preferences: Labour and Conservative England supporters would prefer to see their parties win the election rather than see Harry Kane and co lift the Euros cup, Savanta polling reveals. Some 70 percent of Labour-voting England fans would prefer to see Labour win the election over England winning the competition, while 64 percent of Conservative-voting England supporters said the same about their own side. Nerds, the lot of you.\n\nOverall: Labour holds a 24-point lead over the Tories among football fans -- with 45 percent support compared with 21 percent. But the public overall reckons Rishi Sunak would make a better PM than Gareth Southgate (35 percent to 28 percent) ... so it's not all doom and gloom for the PM.\n\nSpeaking of polls: YouGov noted an uptick in Conservative support and a slip for both Labour and Reform. The poll was done a few days before the gambling row properly erupted.\n\nChoose your own polling: Just to complicate everything, the latest from Redfield and Wilton shows ... Reform up and the Tories down.\n\nVITAL LISTENING: The latest episode of Radio 4 show More or Less debunks a long list of recent nonsensical election claims. It explains how Labour maths on homeowners facing \u00a34,800 more on their mortgage bills under the Tories is not worth the paper it's written on ... how government claims about English kids being the best readers in the world are misleading (because other nations fell back during the pandemic and England is testing kids further into their education) ... and how there are *not* more potholes on British roads than craters on the moon, as Labour has claimed.\n\nNEW LEASE OF LIFE: Playbook PM superstar Noah Keate has written a thoughtful piece about leasehold, and how campaigners will be breathing down the necks of a Labour government to fix the \"feudal\" regime, after the Tories broke their promises to do so and settled for tinkering. Playbook PM is a grumpy leaseholder, to declare an interest.\n\nSTILL TO COME (SHORT-TERM): The latest Techne poll should drop this evening in the Independent.\n\nSTILL TO COME (LONG TERM): The Boris Johnson account of his time in Downing Street (the whole, unvarnished truth, no doubt) will be out on October 10. The front cover looks like something out of a horror movie -- as the content inside might too.\n\nHAPPY FAMILIES: An aide to Cabinet minister Penny Mordaunt took aim on Twitter at Rishi Sunak's wife and other top Conservative women who hit the campaign trail.\n\nAROUND THE WORLD\n\nRUTTE TO HEAD NATO: Outgoing Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte will be the next NATO secretary-general after all 32 members of the alliance agreed he will succeed Jens Stoltenberg. My colleague Stuart Lau analyzed some of the challenges he will face.\n\nMIDDLE EAST LATEST: Israel's government insisted the war in Gaza will only conclude with the destruction of Hamas after its military spokesperson said the group could not be eradicated. It underlines the rifts between Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and the Israel Defense Forces, via the Times.\n\nIN ROMANIA: The Romanian government promised to send a full Patriot air defense system to Ukraine to help bolster its defenses -- as long as the U.S. helps Romania's own defenses -- my colleague Joshua Posaner has more.\n\nIN CANADA: Canada listed Iran's Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps as a terrorist organization following years of pressure from opposition legislators. The BBC has a writeup.\n\nBOOZING WITH BOSTON: Boston Consulting Group hosts hacks at the Standard Hotel from 5.30 p.m. Invites needed. The England game will be streamed, of course.\n\nTOMORROW'S WORLD\n\nSHIPPING OUT CASH: The Home Office will publish its latest update on payments under the Windrush Compensation Scheme.\n\nTHE OTHER INFLATION: Public sector borrowing and debt stats are due out at 7 a.m.\n\nTHE TRIAL CONTINUES: Labour leader Keir Starmer is expected in Scotland, while Rishi Sunak is expected in Wales.\n\nNEW NUMBERS: Expect new polls from BMG, WeThink and Whitestone, as well as the latest Electoral Calculus seat predictions based on recent polls.\n\nNIGE AND NICK: Reform leader Nigel Farage faces Nick Robinson for a Panorama interview, to be broadcast at 7 p.m.\n\nOVER IN WALES: Welsh political leaders face off in a debate in Cardiff, broadcast on BBC One Wales and the BBC News channel at 7 p.m.\n\nWHAT I'VE BEEN READING: This Unherd piece from Anthony Broxton about the *other* Westminster gambling addiction. In it, he notes the reason governments hesitate to slap more regulations on the sector: \"As of 2023, the industry is estimated to be worth over \u00a314.3 billion and the big winners, beyond the bookmakers, are the Treasury who rake in huge tax revenues. Alleged election betting shows real dedication", "body": "Break out the comedy air quotes, because Tony Lee, the Conservative party's director of campaigning, has taken a \"leave of absence\". A development to which one's immediate response is: wait, this Conservative campaign has a director??? Does he work in the snuff genre? If not, this is surely the Heaven's Gate of general election campaigns - and you have to remember that fabled cinematic flop collapsed not simply an entire genre (the western), nor simply an entire legacy movie studio (United Artists), but the entire promise-filled era of film-making known as the New Hollywood.\n\nRighto: metaphors. In the weeks leading up to Rishi Sunak's general election announcement, you would think the one thing the party who'd been in charge for the past 14 years wasn't short of was metaphors. Britain was now a country whose own excrement was literally lapping at its shores.\n\nBritain was now a country whose prime minister travelled from central London to Manchester to announce that the government's flagship central-London-to-Manchester rail project would no longer be going to Manchester - or indeed to central London. The list went on.\n\nRelated: Gambling watchdog looks into second Tory candidate over alleged election bet\n\nSay what you will about recent administrations, but you absolutely could not question the commitment to creating their own metaphors. It was quite possibly our last manufacturing success story.\n\nWhich brings us to the revelation that two Tory parliamentary candidates are under investigation by the Gambling Commission for placing bets on the election date before it was formally announced by Sunak.\n\nLast week the Guardian revealed that Sunak's closest parliamentary aide, Craig Williams, had placed a \u00a3100 bet on the date. Yesterday evening, the BBC revealed that a police officer in Sunak's protection detail had been arrested and suspended over an election timing bet. Hours later, the BBC revealed that a second Conservative candidate, named as Bristol North West hopeful Laura Saunders, was also being probed for allegedly placing a bet on the election date. Then this morning, the Beeb revealed that someone else - oh do look, it's campaigns director Tony Lee himself! - was being looked into over an alleged bet related to the timing of the election.\n\nPlease take a moment to create a fantasy scenario as to how on earth this hugely unfortunate series of events occurred. Did someone - perhaps the director of Conservative campaigns - take a look at the party's prospects and spot a gap in the metaphor market? Did Tony Lee issue some form of APB, perhaps along the lines of: \"Guys, we can see that Labour is just short of one metaphor - specifically something to illustrate the idea that we gambled with the country to enrich ourselves. For the love of God, can anyone help them out?\" I want to say: look, if you want a job doing, etc. But I think that legally, I am required to say: if allegedly you want an alleged job allegedly doing, etc.\n\nAs for what precisely we're dealing with - you always see the bookies' publicists press-releasing odds on things like the next election date, or who killed a Coronation Street character or something. When I worked on this paper's Diary column, we'd sometimes ring those PRs and claim we wanted to place a bet on these supposed markets, in the interests of seeing if they actually existed in the real world, or were just a publicity trick. There would always be an incredible amount of waffle in reply. The fact is, the bookmakers watch these novelty markets incredibly closely, as they are so vulnerable to punters with inside information. So what is being alleged here is not just irregular betting, but intense stupidity.\n\nHow many stupids are there? By lunch, the Conservative campaign HQ had issued a statement saying \"it wouldn't be proper to comment\", adding that they had been contacted about \"a small number of individuals\". Why not say three? Oh man - it's not more than three ... is it?\n\nThis was not a question answered by the various Conservatives on the campaign trail today. Touring the breakfast studios was Michael Gove, who regretted being unable to discuss an ongoing investigation, before waltzing onwards and breezing of the party's electoral prospects: \"We're not in Fergie time yet!\"\n\nOnce again, we can only salute a senior politician's unique understanding of football terminology. But in the interests of accuracy: Michael, it would be good for the Conservatives if you were in Fergie time, because it would mean you might be about to pull off an astonishing late-stage winner with the clock arguably running on till you did. An alternative analogy for this particular general election campaign might be the infamous Nigerian match in which Akurba FC lost 79-0 to Plateau United Feeders, with the Feeders scoring a goal every 37 seconds in the second half. The Nigerian Football Association called it \"a mind-boggling show of shame\". And lifetime bans ensued.\n\nElsewhere, Jeremy Hunt already seemed to be on the memoir circuit. This morning the guy who is still actually chancellor of the exchequer told a story to something called the Times CEO Summit - big campaigning stop, apparently - about how he got his job.\n\n\"I got that rather unexpected call from Liz Truss asking me to be chancellor,\" reflected Hunt. \"Which I thought was a hoax and refused to take the call and could not imagine any situation ever where Liz Truss would actually ask me to be chancellor, so that was a bit surreal, and then in that first week literally I'm picking the entire mini-budget!\"\n\nSorry - is it not still the election? Why is he reminding people of this lunacy? Is there a point at which play becomes so remarkably atrocious that it could even amount to alleged election-throwing? {"uri": "8187780488", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "22:28:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T22:28:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T22:26:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/uk-pm-sunak-angry-after-party-figures-ensnared-in-election-betting-scandal/article_a334cf95-7905-5344-8536-519dc164d481.html", "title": "UK PM Sunak 'angry' after party figures ensnared in election betting scandal", "body": "Prime Minister Rishi Sunak was ignored by a flock of sheep as he tried to feed them in southwest England\n\nPrime Minister Rishi Sunak said Thursday he was \"incredibly angry\" after more Conservative Party figures were put under investigation over alleged bets placed on the UK general election date.\n\nFacing questions on the growing scandal from an audience of voters on live television, the beleaguered leader said any election candidates or officials found to have broken rules would be kicked out of the party.\n\nHis comments came hours after the Conservatives' campaign director stepped aside following reports that he and his wife, a Tory candidate in the July 4 election, were under investigation by betting regulators.\n\nLast week, another would-be MP, Craig Williams, who was a Sunak ministerial aide, was also being probed for staking \u00a3100 ($127) on the date before it was called.\n\nLondon police said Wednesday that one of the prime minister's police security detail had been arrested for allegedly placing a bet on the date.\n\n\"I was incredibly angry... to learn of these allegations,\" Sunak said of the cases involving his party officials.\n\n\"If anyone is found to have broken the rules, not only should they face the full consequences of the law, I will make sure that they are booted out of the Conservative Party,\" he added.\n\n- 'Astonishing' -\n\nThe Conservatives confirmed earlier that campaign director Tony Lee had started \"a leave of absence\" and that the Gambling Commission was looking into \"a number of individuals\".\n\nThe regulator did not name individuals but the BBC reported that Lee and his election candidate wife Laura Saunders were under investigation.\n\nHer lawyers said she would \"be co-operating with the Gambling Commission\" and claimed the report infringed her privacy rights.\n\nThe commission had already said it was looking at the claims regarding Williams.\n\nPolitical bets are allowed in the UK, including on the date of elections, but using insider knowledge to do so is against the law.\n\nThe inquiries heap further misery on Sunak, whose party has trailed Labour by about 20 points in the polls for nearly two years, making it odds on to be dumped out of office after 14 years.\n\nLabour's campaign co-ordinator Pat McFadden wrote to Sunak arguing the claims showed \"a pattern of behaviour\" by the Tories focused on making \"a quick profit\".\n\nMore from this section Should women be required to register for military draft? Some lawmakers say yes Davies given Canada captaincy ahead of Copa opener with Argentina Barack Obama Guides Joe Biden Off Stage As He Freezes Up At Fundraiser Event Watch\n\nOpposition Labour leader Keir Starmer, tipped to become prime minister, has urged Sunak to withdraw support for those allegedly involved.\n\n\"It's astonishing that we're in this place... Rishi Sunak just needs to take action. He needs to account for exactly who knew what,\" he said.\n\nBut at Thursday's debate, Sunak insisted it was \"right\" that the probes were conducted \"thoroughly\" and \"confidentially\" before anyone is sanctioned.\n\n\"The integrity of that process should be respected,\" he said.\n\n- Wipe-out? -\n\nSunak announced the date of the election on May 22, in a rain-soaked statement outside Downing Street, taking his own party by surprise as he still had six months to call a vote.\n\nCritics lambasted him for not using an umbrella and the campaign has hardly shifted the dial in his favour since, even with indications the British economy has turned a corner.\n\nThis week, he was ignored by a flock of sheep as he tried to feed them in southwest England while his personal ratings suffered after he left early from a D-Day 80th anniversary commemoration event.\n\nTwo polls published on Wednesday predicted a record win for Labour, eclipsing even the landslide victory for Labour's Tony Blair in 1997.\n\nPollsters YouGov said the Conservatives could slump to their \"lowest seat tally in the party's almost 200-year history\".\n\nSunak could even become the first sitting prime minister to lose his own seat, according to a Savanta survey.\n\nLondon police said a member of the Royalty and Specialist Protection Command, was held on Monday on suspicion of misconduct in a public office, then released on bail.\n\nThe allegations against Williams came to light last week. He is alleged to have placed a bet on a July date for the election three days before Sunak called the vote.\n\nbur-jj/tw", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro
